Case study

Teaching compassion as a strong skill

Role

UX Research

Why this project is important to me

In 2018, Jeff Weiner, then CEO of LinkedIn, approached EVERFI to develop a product that taught compassion in the classroom. His goal was to have every US student be able to define "compassion" and we had to find out from teachers and parents how best to do that.

Our internal LX and UX teams worked with an outside game design firm to craft an experience that would be easy for teachers to use in the classroom and would not require every student to have access to a computer.

TL;DR:

Working with teachers to define compassion.

1 of 5

Discovery

We interviewed teachers from across the US to understand how to integrate the topic of compassion into their classroom.

2 of 5

Findings

We discovered that most classrooms didn't have enough computers for every student. We also learned that supplemental offline material like worksheets would be beneficial.

3 of 5

Next steps

We began developing an experience that would ask students to watch, discuss, and act. Videos, digital games, and worksheets and posters would drive the program.

4 of 5

Validate

Surveys with teachers and testing with students verified ideas and helped us pivot when needed. We never lost sight of building an experience that was fun for students and easy for teachers.

5 of 5

Build

Supplemanting the digital experience with paper products increased our reach and impact. Talking with teachers helped us focus on creative analog solutions as well as digital ones.

Discovery

After initially meeting with and surveying teachers we learned that most schools had a limited amount of student computers. Even though most teachers had a way of presenting videos in the classroom, the team needed to get creative and develop more than high-quality video games. Our initial findings revealed:

  • We needed to think beyond digital solutions,
  • The experience had to be seamless for teachers and the classroom, and
  • We needed to develop a strategy to measure success

The team went to work developing videos and digital games while exploring analog solutions like scenario-based card games and interactive posters for the classroom.

Sketches of games and screens from Discovery sessions

Development

The team began working on games like the "Mindful Maze", a game that has students achieve goals while being mindful of their character's anxiety when encountering stressful situations. In the experience, simply stopping and breathing allows the player's "stress meter" to cool-off. Another game we called "Empathy Goggles" gave players an opportunity to explore other people's perspectives. These interactions gave students a sandbox to practice their social-emotional skills.

We knew we needed more than digital interactions. The LX team began developing offline lesson plans and materials to print and use in the classroom. One of these ideas was scenario cards that gave examples of opportunities to show compassion. These ideas allowed teachers to start discussions or put into action the skills the students were learning from the lessons.

Scenario Card 1

Recess

  • Someone doesn’t have anyone to play with
  • Someone lost a game and feels very upset
  • Someone doesn’t understand the rules of the game everyone is playing

Scenario Card 2

Ouch!

  • Someone fell off their bike and hurt themselves
  • Someone tripped in the classroom and dropped all of their stuff
  • Someone hit their head really hard

Scenario Card 3

Lunchtime

  • Someone is sitting by themselves
  • Someone has a food allergy and can’t sit at the table with the rest of the class
  • Someone dropped their lunch on the ground, and it got stepped on

Scenario Card 4

Feeling Nervous

  • Someone has a big test coming up at school, and they’re feeling scared about it
  • Someone has to go to the doctor today to get shots, and they’re afraid of needles
  • Someone has stage fright for their upcoming concert

Scenario cards developed for offline lessons

Validate

The Compassion Project launched in 2019 in partnership with the U.S. Women’s National Soccer Team Players Association. The program has reached 17,000 schools, roughly 20% of all primary schools in the U.S.

The course has achieved a net-promoter score of 75, with 98% of teachers rating the course as “good” or “very good.”

Research shows that for every dollar invested in social-emotional learning, we see an $11 return to society in the form of student academic outcomes and long-term career success. Feedback from teachers has illuminated how impactful this program has been for both individual students and their classrooms, especially since the pandemic.

Games that teach prevention
